posts.name: 郭庭瑋
posts.cooked: We are trying to control a seesaw-like structure where the power source is located at the center (the pivot point of the seesaw). We are currently using only the P and I components of a PID controller, but we are unable to achieve the fastest and most stable control. Is there any method that can help us improve our control? Should we consider using feedforward control? If anyone knows how to solve this, we would greatly appreciate it. Thank you!

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Typically, PIDs are tuned P, then D, THEN I. Try using P and D rather than P and I.

posts.name: 郭庭瑋
posts.cooked: Okay, we’ll give it a try, but I still wonder if using feedforward would be better?

posts.name: Joseph Farkas
posts.cooked: A lot more context would be helpful in making this decision. Firstly, what variables go into controlling the system (i.e. gravity, position of end-effectors, etc). Also, how is the system controlled (on the motor controller, on the rio, etc). Finally, seeing the current behavior and symptoms would help in identifying the true cause of the “problems” you face. As a general rule, feed-forward allows a system to be predictive rather than reactive, empowering smoother and more stable control, however it is often possible and easier to produce good results without it.

posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked: I did not really understand what is the system here, but if you are looking for something stable, feedforward will likely help you. Altough as @MrRedness said, more context will help here

Start by trying WPILib ArmFeedforward . Set PID to 0 and tune the FF with gravity and mass distribution or use SysID if that is something you do. Get as close as possible then:

EricH:

P, then D, THEN I

posts.name: 郭庭瑋
posts.cooked: We are using CANSparkMax controllers, and the entire mechanism looks like this: shooter.jpg - Google Drive . We experience significant shaking in the structure when shooting from a distance. We are looking for ways to minimize this as much as possible (excluding tolerances). If you have any insights, that would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

posts.name: 郭庭瑋
posts.cooked:
We once considered using feedforward control. Here is the code we used at that time:

We are not sure if this approach is feasible.

Okay, there are a few things you can do here.

First, call motor.set() instead of motor.setVoltage() . setVoltage() sets the exact voltage number rather than commanding an output percentage.

You are going to want to use ArmFeedforward instead of SimpleMotorFeedforward . ArmFeedforward can compensate for the forces on the pivot changing with gravity by multiplying the output by the cosine of the pivot angle. Remember to multiply the encoder reading by 2π to convert to radians.

After that, you will probably want to use it by calling setGoal() in however you make your commands.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: We typically advise people to use setVoltage() rather than set() for things like PID control, because setVoltage() will not vary in behavior based on battery voltage, while set() does.  Basically setVoltage() is doing voltage compensation, so removing one source of control variability.
Would calling enableVoltageCompensation() on the SparkMAX also work? Not sure if it is exactly the same, but it should have the same effect.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
William123:

We experience significant shaking in the structure when shooting from a distance.

You don’t indicate if it’s the variation in flywheel speed that causes the shaking (but not at all speeds) or if it’s the variation in pivot angle that causes the shaking (but not at all angles). And I’m assuming you mean the shaking is introduced by the pivot PID controller overshooting the setpoint and trying to return but again overshooting the setpoint on the other side of it.

Backlash in the mechanism (your chain drive it looks like) can be hard to control as mentioned in other CD threads. You can compensate a little with your software but mostly the mechanism has to be designed and built well. Chain tensioners and gas springs can help (as can constant force springs in some situations). My team used good gears (total 200:1 and a right angle) to drive the pivot and we balanced it with, I think, two 15-pound gas springs (probably 15 pounds extension and 18 pounds compression).

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: I see a through-bore encoder on your pivot axle.  Are you attempting to use that as the primary measurement of the pivot angle for feedback control or are you using it to initialize your motor encoder and using the motor encoder as the measurement of the pivot angle?  If using the through-bore, backlash in the mechanisms that drive the pivot will cause enough decoupling of the control effort (spin the motor shaft) and the measurement of the pivot angle to destabilize a feedback control loop.  The backlash would have to be minimal or the controller should be using the motor encoder for measurement.  Of course, if you use the motor encoder for measurement and still have a lot of mechanical backlash, your shooting accuracy is going to be compromised ( a huge issue for Crescendo, where being a degree off kills long shots), but at least it should be possible to stabilize the controller.

posts.name: 郭庭瑋
posts.cooked: We have considered using constant force springs due to the low elevation angle when shooting at a distance (I suspect the tolerance between the hex shaft and the gear may have a significant impact) combined with the influence of the flywheel speed. If this is the issue, is there a better solution? Thank you again for your response.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
You haven’t indicated whether the “shaking” is mechanical in nature or is being driven by the controller.  When moving to a new arm angle, does your motor voltage become a steady value, does it oscillate up and down for a little while, and then become steady, or does it oscillate up and down and never become steady?

If the motor voltage quickly becomes steady, but you still have arm shaking, working on the mechanism to take up backlash (like with a constant force spring) has the potential to help.  Another thing you could do is make sure you are using a trapezoidal angle setpoint profile with a feedforward and feedback ( PID ) controller and limiting the setpoint velocity to no more than the velocity the arm is capable of traveling. Also limit the setpoint acceleration so the arm settles in to its goal angle a bit more smoothly and doesn’t carry as much momentum to start mechanical vibration.  Your arm/shooter structure looks pretty stiff from the photo, so I would not expect “shaking” due to elastic bending of the structure as it gets moved back and forth by the pivot torque.  It would still be good to at least verify that you can’t detect any bending if you put force on it (e.g. clamp the structure at the pivot and try to bend it by hand).

If your motor voltage is oscillating for a short time, your feedback tuning may be too aggressive.  Make sure your feedforward is as accurate as possible so the feedback controller has very little work to do.  You should not need I (integral mode) for your arm angle.  I’d recommend trying to keep kI at 0. Integral can quickly destabilize a loop. You should be able to get very good control with feedforward + P.  A little bit of D can help if you are trying for the fastest possible loop while minimizing  setpoint overshoot, but you probably have a long way to go with feedforward and P before considering D.

If your motor voltage is oscillating for a long time, be sure that you aren’t trying to control “noise” that would be coming from arm movements within the backlash zone.  Use the motor encoder for your controller measurement rather than the pivot axle encoder to eliminate backlash noise in the loop.  If you try to dampen backlash mechanically with constant force springs, shimming hex bores between gears/sprockets/pulleys and axles, changing to belts rather than chains, etc. you might get better results using the pivot axle encoder, but you should still do best overall using the motor encoder.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Another possibility is you are over-speeding the pivot with too low of a reduction ratio for a high-speed motor. As I mentioned my team’s robot has 200:1 with a Falcon 500 and it gets to the setpoint very fast.

posts.name: 郭庭瑋
posts.cooked: Please forgive my ignorance, but I still want to know what the difference is between using ArmFeedforward and SimpleMotorFeedforward. As you can see in my calculateFeedForward() method, I indeed implemented multiplying the output by the cosine of the pivot angle to compensate for the pivot. What is the difference between them?

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
ArmFeedforward has the arm position built-in to the calculate method.  It’s the first argument.  The calculation handles the gravity force.  You don’t need external augmentation to deal with gravity.

SimpleMotorFeedforward does not have position built-in to the calculate method because it’s not intended to model feedforward compensation for an arm.  You could use this in a complicated manner like you have and handle the gravity force yourself, but you don’t need to if you use ArmFeedforward.
Your exact implementation is slightly different in that you add the sine of the angle not the sine of the velocity. This is how ArmFeedforward calculates:
